As a first time player, your choice is between pursuing a lot of side objectives that you may not care about in order to keep yourself leveled up for the challenges ahead or throw all your upgrade points into the batmobile so you can handle the next bs section where they throw 50 tanks at you without tearing your hair out.

Big Batman enthusiast, huge fan of the character, love the Arkham series but oh my god man. This review isn't about the performance or the port, I know how terribly this game launched on PC. I'm not here to talk about how broken the PC port was a decade ago; it ran fine for me, I just think it's a bad game. 

Arkham Knight looks amazing graphically, I can't deny that, but that's most of what it has going for it. From a narrative and game design standpoint, this game is an absolute mess, especially when compared to City. I didn't want to harp too much on the batmobile, just because everyone does, but its such a consistent part of the experience that I kind of have no choice. It's really fun for the first 20 minutes you can use it! And then, you've exhausted all three of its functions and it starts to get really stale really fast. And while a lot of its usage earlier on is optional, Rocksteady makes it so unbearable, especially later into the game. Flooding you with vehicular combat encounters that wouldn't feel out of place in World of Tanks, except here its even clunkier. Not to mention it's miserable to control. The best use of it in the whole game is a boss fight where you're literally just running away. Because for once, it's being used for something different. Even outside the batmobile though, a lot of the hand to hand combat and stealth is just mind-numbing to me. 
The predator encounters here have the same problem they did in Arkham Origins, wherein the first few are pretty neat and not all that bad, but the longer the game progresses, the more repetitive they feel. Every single area they take place in has the same layout, every single endgoal has the same function, the only thing Rocksteady does to keep things fresh is to just throw more enemies in the encounter to take care of. It's not fun, or engaging or interesting, it's just boring. The hand to hand combat is a bit more complicated. I can't deny that its undoubtedly the smoothest it ever was, but that's kind of why I don't like it? It's admittedly a total nitpick on my part, but part of why I liked the combat in Asylum or City or even Origins is that despite the fact that they got smoother over time (the jump between Asylum and City is insane), they still had this rough around the edges feel that made the combat feel just a bit more engaging to me. I always felt a sense of difficulty because of it. It made every combat encounter, especially boss fights, feel so much more tense. Knight doesn't really have this, because its too smooth. The only moments that truly feel dire are when Rocksteady lazily floods your screen with more enemies than you can keep track of (yet another problem carried over from Origins).

I also just am not a very big fan of the story here. I know Paul Dini and Rocksteady parted ways after Arkham City. It shows by how much weaker the writing is in this game. I like the Joker stuff, to be fair. I think of all the ways Rocksteady could've utilized Joker after Arkham City, this was far from the worst way they could've done it. Vastly preferable to just bringing him back as a genuine figment of reality. I also appreciate this game's willingness to explore Bruce as a character with a sense of depth that Asylum and City didn't. But those upsides can only go so far. Not only is the story a victim of awful pacing, but it's comically anticlimactic in more ways than one. Firstly, I love the fact that when Rocksteady was marketing this game, they talked lots about how they were introducing a completely original character to their story, and how the Arkham Knight was going to be completely new. And then it turned out to be Jason Todd. And not just that, but it wasn't even a good or interesting Red Hood adaptation either. Turning him into this domestic terrorist with daddy issues was so uninteresting and boring and a waste of so much potential. The reveal that it's him is so underwhelming, the subsequent boss fight is barely even a boss fight, and his exit from the story is laughable. Even Scarecrow doesn't amount to much here. He looks cool, he sounds cool and should be cool, but he's barely even in the game for one. His presence is barely felt when you're spending most of your time trying to go after the Arkham Knight, and even the nightmare sequences are a step down from what they were in Asylum. That 'final boss' sequence with those 30 Jokers is so uninspired. This game's main story is only about 17-18 hours, but it feels so much longer. It feels like the nice visuals serve to delude people into thinking this game is so much better than it really is, when all it really boils down to is little more than a 'hype moments and aura' Batman montage. It's not even just disappointing as a followup to Arkham City, it's a poorly made video game on its own merits, with that extra context making it feel even more bitter.
